p.s: Description of Rhodovulum kholense sp. nov.
Rhodovulum kholense (kho.len′se. N.L. neut. adj. kholense pertaining to Khola, from where the type strain was isolated).
Cells are ovoid, 0.5–1.0 μm wide and 1.5–1.8 μm long, motile and multiply by binary fission.
Gram-negative.
Growth occurs under anaerobic conditions in the light (photolithoautotrophy and photo-organoheterotrophy) and under aerobic conditions in the dark (chemo-organoheterotrophy).
Internal photosynthetic membranes are of the vesicular type.
Phototrophic cultures are yellow to brown, while aerobic cultures are pink.
The in vivo absorption spectrum of intact cells grown in sucrose exhibits maxima at 377, 468, 520, 590, 803 and 857 nm.
The absorption spectrum of pigments extracted with acetone has absorption maxima at 455 and 485 nm.
Bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids of the spheroidene series are present as photosynthetic pigments.
The organism is mesophilic, with growth observed at 20–35 °C (optimum at 30 °C).
Growth occurs at a pH optimum of 6.0–7.0 (range 6.0–8.0).
NaCl concentrations of 1.0–4.0 % (w/v) (range 0.05–6 %, w/v) are required for optimal growth.
Photo-organoheterotrophy with various organic compounds is the preferred mode of growth.
Carbon sources for good growth include acetate, pyruvate and intermediates of the citric acid cycle, except citrate.
Growth also occurs on glutamate, caproate, caprylate, valerate, glucose, lactate, butyrate, gluconate, ascorbate, peptone and Casamino acids.

Citrate, mannitol, sorbitol, ethanol, formate, sodium potassium tartarate, benzoate, crotonate, glycolate, glycerol, propionate, methanol, thioglycolate, propanol and cysteine are not utilized for growth.

Chemolithoautotrophy [aerobically in the dark with thiosulfate (0.5 mM) as the electron donor and NaHCO3 (0.1 % w/v)] and fermentative growth [anaerobically in the dark with pyruvate (0.3 %, w/v)] could not be demonstrated.
Thiosulfate, sulfate, thioglycolate, cysteine and sodium sulfide are utilized as sulfur sources under photo-organoheterotrophic conditions, but not sulfite, elemental sulfur or methionine.
Ammonium chloride, molecular nitrogen, glutamate, glutamine and aspartate are utilized as nitrogen sources, but not nitrate, nitrite or urea.
Biotin, niacin and thiamine are required as growth factors.
The DNA base composition is 63 mol% G+C (by HPLC).
The type strain, JA297T (=ATCC BAA-1544T=JCM 14888T=CCUG 55397T), was isolated from a mud sample from Bhitarkanika mangrove forest, Khola, Orissa State, India.
